column1: Quelle puce est probablement en cause dans la 2√®me pand√©mie de peste en Europe occidentale ?
column3: Pulex irritans
column7:
Puce suspect√©e dans la 2√®me pand√©mie de peste en Europe occidentale

Pulex irritans est identifi√© comme le seul vecteur potentiel de la peste en Europe occidentale pendant la deuxi√®me pand√©mie. Cette conclusion s'appuie sur plusieurs arguments :

Son adaptation aux climats plus froids, contrairement √† Xenopsylla cheopis (Source 1, Confiance √©lev√©e).
Sa sp√©cificit√© et son abondance sur l'homme (Source 1, Confiance √©lev√©e).
Des arguments √©cologiques, √©pid√©miologiques, et m√™me linguistiques renforcent cette hypoth√®se (Source 1, Confiance moyenne).
Xenopsylla cheopis, la puce du rat, est exclue car elle est li√©e √† des climats chauds ou temp√©r√©s-chauds, alors que les conditions m√©t√©orologiques en Europe occidentale √©taient plus froides pendant cette p√©riode (Source 1, Confiance √©lev√©e).

Conclusion :
La puce Pulex irritans semble √™tre le vecteur le plus probable de la peste en Europe occidentale lors de la deuxi√®me pand√©mie.
column8:
Okay, so I need to figure out which flea was responsible for the second plague pandemic in Western Europe based on the given sources. Let me go through each source one by one and see what information they provide.

Looking at Source 1, it mentions that Xenopsylla cheopis is associated with warm or mild climates. But during the Little Ice Age (XIV to XIX century), temperatures were lower than now, making it impossible for this flea to survive in Western Europe. Instead, it points towards Pulex irritans as the potential vector because of its abundance on humans and ecological factors.

Source 2 talks about different types of fleas and their host specificity. It mentions that Xenopsylla cheopis wasn't found in northern areas like Britain during the 16th and 17th centuries, which were part of the second plague pandemic. This supports the idea that Pulex irritans might have been the vector there since it's more adapted to cooler climates.

Source 3 is similar to Source 1, reinforcing that Xenopsylla cheopis couldn't survive in Europe during that time due to colder temperatures and questioning how the plague spread so effectively if this flea wasn't present. It again highlights Pulex irritans as a likely candidate with supporting ecological and epidemiological evidence.

Source 4 discusses the absence of Xenopsylla cheopis in northern Europe and how it's an introduced species in Europe, possibly from tropical regions. This further solidifies that Pulex irritans must have been the vector because the oriental rat flea wasn't present or couldn't survive the cold winters.

Putting all this together, every source points away from Xenopsylla cheopis being the vector in Western Europe during the second pandemic due to climate and geographical reasons. Instead, they consistently identify Pulex irritans as the probable flea responsible for spreading the plague.

Xeno- psylla cheopis.
Titre anglais : On the vector of Plague in western Europe during the second
                    pandemia.
SuMmMary : The involvement of rats in the spreading of plague in western Europe,
                    and especially in France, has been probably overestimated a posteriori. Because,
                    the oriental rat flea, Xenopsylla cheopis, ecologically attached to warm or mild
                    climates, could not have been the vector insect. In addition, temperatures in
                    the XIV-XIXth cen- tury period (Little Ice Age) were even lower than at the
                    present time, when this species is totally absent. Everything indicates Pulex
                    irritans as the only potential vector : its specificity and extreme abundance in
                    man, and also ecological, epidemiological, or even linguistic arguments.
Key-words : Bubonic plague - Western Europe - Vectors - Pulex irritans -
                    Xenopsylla cheopis.
Re√ßu pour publication le 8.11.95 233 Introduction Il est beaucoup de probl√®mes

                    des solutions nouvelles. La Peste, et plus particuli√®rement la deuxi√®me pand√©mie
                    semble une illustration de ce fait. Je vais donc essayer de r√©envi- sager les
                    probl√®mes plus ou moins r√©cemment resurgis √† ce propos en relation avec son
                    aspect vectoriel. Ce sera donc essentiellement le point de vue d'un
                    entomologiste.
Parmi les propositions "√©tonnantes" on peut citer celles de Twigg qui en vient √†
                    nier la r√©alit√© de la Peste europ√©enne et propose, au moins pour les Iles
                    Britanni- ques, diverses autres √©tiologies pour expliquer les flamb√©es de la
                    2√®me pand√©mie : il s'agirait de charbon (Twigg, 1984) ' et/ou d'affections
                    virales ou bact√©riennes √† conta- giosit√© a√©rienne (Twigg, 1989).
Le raisonnement de Twigg (1989) se base essentiellement sur un syllo- gisme que
                    l'on peut r√©sumer ainsi : la peste est due √† la piq√ªre infectante de la puce du
                    rat, Xenopsylla cheopis : or X. cheopis ne pouvait exister √† cette √©poque en
